parts.title: Challenges in Traditional Organization Design
parts.body: The book, "Strategies for Organization Design", by Tiffany McDowell, highlights common pitfalls of traditional organization structures, focusing on three major challenges: disconnection between design decisions and behavior, focus solely on individual fixes, and neglecting horizontal networks. McDowell offers a solution with a new approach that links high-level organizational decisions with individual and group behaviors influenced by the environment. She emphasizes using network insights for systemic change and improving collaboration and performance by making invisible dynamics within organizations visible.

parts.title: Strategies for Organization Design
parts.body: ## 6 Strategies for Organization Design Hierarchy is only one type of network among many. Traditional organizational charts don't reflect most of the knowledge flows within organizations. Thanks to data and analytics, we can now visualize various networks: work, social, innovation, expert knowledge, career guidance/strategic, and learning networks. We've focused on the hierarchical network, which only accounts for about 20% of the knowledge in organizations; the remaining 80% has been largely ignored. By analyzing trust relationships through network analysis, we can fundamentally transform organizations by understanding horizontal networks and ensuring the right connections are made to facilitate knowledge exchange. This intentional structuring can enhance collective intelligence rather than leaving things to chance. ## Problems with Current Organization Design Many people are disengaged at work, with high levels of burnout and disatisfaction resulting in productivity losses. Achieving modern workforce engagement requires replacing outdated corporate structures and reducing unnecessary bureaucracy and internal mechanisms that consume crucial resources. Organizations need to leverage network science to enhance connections, meaning, belonging, and collaboration to unleash collective potential and improve culture. Effective design should be informed by industrial psychology, organization theory, and other disciplines to create a harmonious system benefiting all workers. The approach proposed combines these insights to make all aspects of organization design harmonize and work together for a more positive outcome.

parts.title: Consulting to Improve Hospital Performance Using Network Analysis
parts.body: A large health system hired a consultant to help improve their hospital performance across 20 locations. The president noticed stark differences in performance between hospitals, revealing a matter of life and death. Despite similar structures, these hospitals had varied outcomes. The consultant and the president began by reviewing the provided information like organization charts and performance metrics but ultimately decided to look into the informal networks within these hospitals. Traditional organization charts represent formal roles but not informal interactions essential for learning and knowledge exchange. The informal networks are key to effective organization functioning. Focusing on networks opens doors to understanding behaviors, influence, and potential improvements. The greatest opportunity for organizations is to design a horizontal or lateral structure to leverage these elements. This consulted approach emphasizes the centrality of relationships and the power of well-positioned individuals to influence others.

parts.title: Balancing Networks and Hierarchies
parts.body:
Key Insights on Networks and Organizations

Organizations need to maintain balance between hierarchy and networks. Influencers play a significant role by integrating multiple channels of communication. However, echoes and double counting can create biases; leading you to believe opinions are independent while they actually just confirm your own. Homophily, the tendency to associate with similar others, leads to silo mentality in organizations, where different teams (e.g., sales vs. marketing) are disconnected, fueling competition rather than cooperation. Recognizing these dynamics can help restructure networks to become more balanced and less biased, providing an untapped competitive advantage.

parts.title: Measurement Techniques and Effects
parts.body:
Measurement Techniques and Effects

Setting goals and measuring progress seems logical, but it can have unintended impacts on behavior. Measurement is essential but should be approached carefully, considering its effects on compensation and motivation. Performance reviews often lead to negative outcomes and are largely disliked due to their inherent biases and detachment from real-time feedback. Negative feedback may inhibit learning, whereas positive attention fosters higher performance. The discrepancy between actual performance and review processes further supports these criticisms. Effectively integrating performance evaluation with real-time feedback acknowledges individuals' efforts, as demonstrated in acknowledgment vs. ignored performance studies by Ariely. Organizational design can be hindered by poorly aligned metrics that emphasize individual rather than collaborative goals, leading to inefficiencies. Shared goals developed through collaborative P&L models might improve processes by harmonizing financial and operational metrics. At Apple, for instance, working under one P&L fosters innovation without intra-company conflicts. To successfully implement shared or collective goals, companies need to empower teams, reducing overemphasis on individual metrics, and focusing on shared enterprise achievements.

parts.title: Shared Fate and Group Success
parts.body: Membership and Organization Design: A shared sense of fate in organizations can explain people's cooperative behavior. Haidt discusses evolutionary psychology — humans are wired for group work and cooperation. People with a shared fate cooperate more, while free riders disrupt this balance. Reputation and shame are key evolutionary traits that motivate individuals to align with group goals. For example, Bregman suggests our actions are driven by our concern for others' opinions. Darwin's theory of multilevel selection implies that those who hold social virtues, such as concern for reputation, tend to succeed. Evolutionary psychology suggests humans seek group membership instinctively, which increases survival chances. Roles and social capital are pivotal, engulfed in a network of social norms and obligations that elevate group goals. In the workplace, roles change behavior patterns, creating bridging ties vital for advancement. Thus, well-defined jobs allow predictable, productive interaction, whereas roles reinforce social identity, paving ways for connection, support, and trust.

parts.title: Leveraging Teams and Diversity Effectively
parts.body: Teams are important for collective success. Stable teams can get things done, but modern work often involves teaming in more fluid arrangements. Professional clashes can hinder growth and innovation. A collective vision focused on a common problem is essential. To create wise groups, information must be shared without bias. Diverse knowledge is often untapped on teams, requiring more focus on information exchange and integration.

parts.title: Embracing Change within Organizations through Peopletecture
parts.body: Organizational change often meets resistance when employees feel forced. The Peopletecture model allows organizations to engage staff level leaders in redesigning their work, boosting engagement. Managers should connect with networks within their teams to bridge silos and better facilitate collaborations. It's critical to lay clear roles and responsibilities while fostering autonomy in alignment with team purposes. Recognizing achievements frequently can uplift morale and productivity.

parts.title: Impact of Social Isolation and Evolving Workplace Dynamics
parts.body: Social isolation is linked to physical health problems and is a cause of burnout in the workplace, defined by WHO as a syndrome from chronic workplace stress. Analysis shows that individuals high in work networks but low in social networks face more burnout. A change in collaboration patterns has occurred, with face-to-face interaction being replaced by less effective methods like emails and large video meetings. This shift has made it tough for employees to maintain social connections and manage workloads within the workday, increasing the average work day by 3 hours (Humanyze 2022). Jeff Schwartz talks about the evolving workplace as a transforming factor for organizations, with network analytics showing the benefits of co-location in Silicon Valley. Proximity positively affects relationships, but hybrid work surveys show a demand for majority remote work. To benefit from organizational networks, individuals need to both manage responsibilities in a hybrid model and be empowered by management systems. Organizations plan the future workplace to enhance event and collaboration spaces, encouraging social engagement to activate trust and community (Haidt 2012). Functional configurations vary by complexity, advocating virtual work for simple tasks and proximity for complex, tacit work.

parts.title: Core References on Organizational Success and Dynamics
parts.body: An array of references and bibliography are provided here, covering a wide range of topics. This chunk highlights the importance of organizations' design and strategy in promoting efficiency and innovation. Authors such as Tiffany McDowell bring expert insights into organizational design technologies and practical contribution towards building successful corporations. Networking and social structures are emphasized as crucial in influencing both individual and group dynamics within companies. Furthermore, there's a strong focus on methods and models that enable better collective performance, involving strategies like role crafting, team empowerment, and collaborative problem-solving aligned with organizational goals. Emphasis is placed on sustaining a positive work environment, ensuring smooth communication, and overcoming obstacles in structure management.
